abstract.text: The common interface for attaching animations to nodes, geometries, materials, and other SceneKit objects.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: SceneKit uses the same architecture as the Core Animation framework, allowing you to animate property changes implicitly or explicitly. For implicit animation, use the
class to quickly create simple animations with very little code. For more complex animations, explicitly create
objects, and use the methods in the
protocol to attach them to the SceneKit objects you want to animate. You also use the methods in this protocol to control any animations already attached to a SceneKit object.

For example, making a node spin continuously for as long as it appears in the scene graph requires explicitly creating an animation that repeats. The following code creates such an animation and attaches it to a node:

code: // Animate one complete revolution around the node's Y axis.
rotationAnimation.duration = 10.0; // One revolution in ten seconds.
rotationAnimation.repeatCount = FLT_MAX; // Repeat the animation forever.
[node addAnimation:rotationAnimation forKey:nil]; // Attach the animation to the node to start it.

abstract.text: The abstract superclass for animations in Core Animation.
Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
The common interface for attaching animations to nodes, geometries, materials, and other SceneKit objects.
Adds an animation object for the specified key.
Returns the animation with the specified key.
An array containing the keys of all animations currently attached to the object.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the animation attached to the object with the specified key is paused.
Pauses the animation attached to the object with the specified key.
Removes all the animations currently attached to the object.
Removes the animation attached to the object with the specified key.
Removes the animation attached to the object with the specified key, smoothly transitioning out of the animation’s effect.
Resumes a previously paused animation attached to the object with the specified key.
A container for a closure, a block in Objective-C, to be executed at a specific time during playback of an animation.
A constraint that orients a node to always point toward the current camera.
A six-sided polyhedron geometry whose faces are all rectangles, optionally with rounded edges and corners.
A set of camera attributes that can be attached to a node to provide a point of view for displaying the scene.
A right circular cylinder geometry whose ends are capped with hemispheres.
A right circular cone or frustum geometry.
The abstract superclass for objects that automatically adjust the position, rotation, or scale of a node based on specified rules.
A right circular cylinder geometry.
A plane that can optionally display a reflection of the scene above it.
A three-dimensional shape (also called a model or mesh) that can be displayed in a scene, with attached materials that define its appearance.
A constraint that applies inverse kinematics to make a chain of nodes “reach” toward a target point.
A light source that can be attached to a node to illuminate the scene.
A constraint that orients a node to always point toward a specified other node.
A set of shading attributes that define the appearance of a geometry’s surface when rendered.
A container for the color or texture of one of a material’s visual properties.
An object that manages smooth transitions between a node’s base geometry and one or more target geometries.
A structural element of a scene graph, representing a position and transform in a 3D coordinate space, to which you can attach geometry, lights, cameras, or other displayable content.
An object that animates and renders a system of small image sprites using a high-level simulation whose general behavior you specify.
A rectangular, one-sided plane geometry of specified width and height.
A right rectangular pyramid geometry.
A scene graph node that serves as a placeholder for content to be loaded from a separate scene file.
A geometry based on a two-dimensional path, optionally extruded to create a three-dimensional object.
A sphere (or ball or globe) geometry.
A specification for augmenting or postprocessing SceneKit’s rendering of a scene using additional drawing passes with custom Metal or OpenGL shaders.
A geometry based on a string of text, optionally extruded to create a three-dimensional object.
A torus, or ring-shaped geometry.
A mechanism for creating implicit animations and combining scene graph changes into atomic updates.
A constraint that runs a specified closure, block in Objective-C, to compute a new transform (position, rotation, and scale) for each node that the constraint affects.
A tube or pipe geometry—a right circular cylinder with a circular hole along its central axis.
Learn about implicit animations, explicit animations, and actions, and when to choose each in your app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
